In the video game industry, 2025 will see the release of Nintendo's next-generation Nintendo Switch 2 console and many new video games.

Top-rated games

[edit]

Critically acclaimed titles

[edit]

The following table lists the top-rated games released in 2025 based on Metacritic, which generally considers expansions as separate entities.

2025 releases scoring 90/100 or higher on Metacritic[1]
Title Developer(s) Publisher(s) Release Platform(s) Average score
Split Fiction Hazelight Studios Electronic Arts March 6, 2025 Win, PS5, XSX/S 91

Major events

[edit]
Month Day(s) Event
January 7–10 New gaming accessories and handheld consoles were revealed during the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) 2025 showcase held at the Las Vegas Convention Center in Winchester, Nevada.[2]
February 11–13 The Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences hosted the 2025 D.I.C.E. Summit and the 28th Annual D.I.C.E. Awards at the Aria Resort and Casino in Las Vegas, Nevada.[3]
25 Warner Bros. Games closed Monolith Productions, Player First Games, and WB Games San Diego.[4]
March 12 Scopely acquires the games division and related intellectual property of Niantic, Inc. for $3.5 billion, which includes Niantic's Pokemon Go and Monster Hunter Now.[5]
17–21 The Game Developers Conference, including the Game Developers Choice Awards and the Independent Game Festival, were held in San Francisco, California.
19 The first industry-wide video game union, the United Videogame Workers-Communication Workers of America, covering both the United States and Canada, is announced.[6]
25 Game Informer announces it had been acquired by Gunzilla Games and re-established themselves as an independant video game news outlet, additionally mentioning a revival of their print magazine and return of all laid off staff members.[7]
27 Ubisoft announces the formation of a four billion euro subsidiary, with a 25% ownership by Tencent, to manage its top franchises including Assassin's Creed and Far Cry.[8]
April 2–13 The 2025 London Games Festival, which comprises New Game Plus, the BAFTA Games Awards, Games Finance Market, Screen Play, Now Play This, The Trafalgar Square Games Festival, Side Events and The London Video Game Orchestra will be held in London, England.[9]
May 9–11 Evo Japan 2025 is scheduled to be held at Tokyo Big Sight in Tokyo.[10]
22 Super Nintendo World is scheduled to open to the public alongside Universal Epic Universe in Florida.[11]
June 6 The 2025 Summer Game Fest is scheduled to be held at the YouTube Theater in Los Angeles.[12][13][14]
August 1–3 The 2025 Evolution Championship Series is scheduled to be held at the Las Vegas Convention Center in Winchester, Nevada.[15]
September 25–28 Tokyo Game Show 2025 is scheduled to be held in the Makuhari Messe, in Chiba, Japan.[16]
December 11 The Game Awards 2025 is scheduled to be held at the Peacock Theater in Los Angeles.[17]

Notable deaths

[edit]
  • January 9 – Alan Emrich, 65, video game writer who coined the term 4X.[18]
  • January 12 – Robert Machray, 79, actor with voice roles in The Dark Eye and Star Wars Rogue Squadron II: Rogue Leader.[19]
  • January 15 – David Lynch, 78, surrealist filmmaker whose work influenced numerous video games, including the Alan Wake series, The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening, Silent Hill 2, Disco Elysium, and Deadly Premonition.[20][21]
  • January 24 – Tetsuhisa Seko, 54, president of Nippon Ichi Software.[22]
  • January 30 – Wayne June, voice actor who was announcer for Dota 2 and narrator of Darkest Dungeon.[23]
  • February 3 – Stéphane Picq, 59, composer who scored Dune, MegaRace, Lost Eden, Atlantis: The Lost Tales, and Riverworld.[24]
  • February 16 – Viktor Antonov, 52, art director of Half-Life 2 and Dishonored.[25]
  • February 21 – Peter Jason, 80, actor with voice roles in Fallout 2 and Gears of War.[26]
  • March 11 – Dave Mallow, 76, voice actor who voiced Akuma in the Street Fighter and Marvel vs. Capcom series.[27]
  • March 12 – Thomas Lee, 59, former EA employee who worked on games such as Final Fantasy IX, Parasite Eve, and Wing Commander III.[28]
  • March 12 – Takashi Inagaki, 87, voice actor who voiced Yen Sid in the Kingdom Hearts series, Epic Mickey, and Epic Mickey 2: The Power of Two.[29]
  • March 25 – Abdulaziz “HAX$” Al-Yami, 30, pro Super Smash Bros. Melee player.[30]
  • April 3 – Narayana "River Boy" Johnson, audio director and composer for Cult of the Lamb.[31]
  • April 5 - Bill Petras, art director for Blizzard Entertainment on several games, including StarCraft, World of Warcraft and Overwatch.[32]
